description: Medium - Causes of War and Rome's Decision to Intervene

questions.question: What was Sicily's political status and importance in the Mediterranean by 264 BCE?
options: Sicily was unified under a single Greek ruler and posed no strategic significance to Rome
Sicily was fragmented politically but wealthy agriculturally, making it a valuable prize for any power
Sicily was completely controlled by Carthage with no independent cities or rival powers present
Sicily was a Roman province already and posed no conflict between Rome and Carthage
Sicily was inhabited only by local Berber peoples with no Greek cities or organized societies

questions.question: How was Sicily's political situation affected by King Pyrrhus's departure from the island in 275 BCE?
options: His departure strengthened Carthage's control completely and ended all internal Sicilian conflicts
His departure left a power vacuum and created uncertainty about the island's political future
His departure resulted in immediate Roman conquest of Sicily without any significant competition
His departure made Syracuse the undisputed ruler of all Sicily and all other territories
His departure had no effect on Sicilian politics since he never exercised any real authority

questions.question: Why was Sicily's agricultural wealth and resource production crucial to Carthage's power and prosperity? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Sicily was the only source of grain and olive oil available anywhere in the Mediterranean region
Sicilian resources funded Carthaginian commerce, military operations, and governmental administration broadly
Sicily provided the only tin supplies Carthage could access for bronze and weapon manufacturing
Sicilian territories allowed Carthage to project naval power and maintain military bases strategically
Sicily's population provided unlimited mercenary soldiers for Carthaginian military operations regularly

questions.question: What internal problems weakened Syracuse's ability to challenge Carthagian dominance in Sicily?
options: Syracuse lacked any significant military or naval forces to resist external military threats
Political factions competed for power within Syracuse creating governmental instability and division
The city was devastated by plague and disease that reduced the population significantly
Syracuse's wealth had been depleted by previous wars with Carthage and other powers
Local populations within Syracuse refused to provide military service or taxation support
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Syracuse and Internal Sicilian Politics

questions.question: Who were the Mamertines and what was their status in Sicily during the 260s BCE? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Former mercenary soldiers primarily from southern Italy who had taken control of Messana
A Sicilian Greek community descended from ancient Greek colonists in northeastern Sicily
A military garrison that controlled Messana's resources, commerce, and port facilities directly
Professional soldiers who supported themselves through piracy and raiding against neighboring territories
A united confederation of Sicilian city-states allied against both Carthage and Rome collectively

questions.question: What motivated Hiero II of Syracuse to threaten the Mamertine-controlled city of Messana?
options: He wanted to expand Syracuse's territory into northern Sicily and control all the island
He viewed the foreign mercenaries as a threat and embarrassment within Sicilian territories
He sought to eliminate them before they could align with Carthage against Syracuse militarily
He needed their resources and population to strengthen Syracuse's military and economic position
He was directly ordered by Carthage to eliminate the independent Mamertine garrison there
questions.text_reference: Section 3: The Mamertines: Mercenary Soldiers Stranded in Sicily

questions.question: Why did the Mamertines appeal to Rome for military assistance against Syracuse and Carthage?
options: Rome had previously promised military protection to all independent Mediterranean cities formally
They faced destruction from both Syracuse and Carthage and saw Rome as a potential ally
They expected Rome would easily defeat both Carthage and Syracuse militarily and quickly
Rome had established trading relationships with Messana and owed military support contractually
They believed Rome needed control of Sicily to expand its Mediterranean commercial networks
questions.text_reference: Section 3: The Mamertines: Mercenary Soldiers Stranded in Sicily

questions.question: What strategic arguments supported Rome's decision to intervene in Sicily militarily in 264 BCE? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Allowing Carthage unchallenged dominance of Sicily posed a potential long-term threat to Rome
Rome's credibility with allies depended on providing military support to threatened allied communities
Rome possessed sufficient resources and institutional capacity for the first time to wage overseas war
The Mamertines promised Rome unlimited financial payments in exchange for military protection permanently
Intervening offered an opportunity to challenge Carthage under favorable strategic circumstances

questions.question: What significant obstacles made military intervention in Sicily risky and costly for Rome? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome's citizen-soldiers were reluctant to serve overseas and preferred defending Italian territories only
Carthage's naval dominance was absolute and Rome lacked significant naval experience or power
The Mamertines were unreliable allies who might switch sides during the military conflict
Rome would have to sustain operations far from home with unprecedented logistical requirements needed
Syracuse possessed a powerful military force that could easily destroy any Roman invasion army

questions.question: How did Carthage respond when Rome intervened militarily in Sicily on behalf of the Mamertines? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Carthage negotiated a peaceful settlement and withdrew from Sicily to avoid conflict with Rome
Carthage viewed Roman intervention as a direct challenge to Carthaginian dominance in the Mediterranean
Carthage recognized that Sicily was no longer valuable and abandoned all territorial claims completely
Carthage mobilized its navy and forces to contest Roman control and defend Sicilian territories
Carthage sought alliances with Rome to jointly control Sicily and exclude Syracuse from power
